A wonderfull story, and the like never heard of in our moderne times, and yet all to manifest the glory and providence of God, in the preservation of Christendome in these troublesome times. Printed this fifteenth of Iuly.

div.p: THE STRANGLING AND DEATH OF THE GREAT TVRKE, AND HIS TWO SONNES.
VVITH THE STRANGE Preſervation and Deliverance of his Vncle MVSTAPHA from periſhing in Priſon, with hunger and thirſt, the young Emperour not three dayes before having ſo commanded.
A WONDERFVLL STORY, and the like never heard of in our M • derne times, and yet all to manifeſt the Glory and Providence of God, in the Preſervation of Chriſtendome in theſe troubleſome Times.
LONDON, Printed by I.D. for Nicholas Bourne and Thomas Archer, and are to be ſold at their ſhops at the Exchange, and in Popes-head Pallace. 1622.

div.head: ❧ The Printer to the Reader.
div.p:
I Am very loath to trouble you with a Preface, yet at this time you muſt pardon me; for it is for Gods cauſe, to exemplifie his glory & providence, that hath put an hook in the noſtrils of Leviathan, and kept him from devouring poore Chriſtians, who yet are in Armes to devoure one another: that hath throwne a ſtone from Heaven to ſtrike the golden Image to powder, which was ſtretching it ſelfe, to overlooke and overtopp the Provinces of Europe; that hath put an Axe to the great tree, and felld it at a blow, which was beginning to overſpread the earth, and be a ſhaddow for the beaſts of the field. What, all Chriſtendome almoſt in Armes, and yet the Turke not to take the advantage, but to be pulld ſhort by the hand of God, and throwne backward into a graue? Where are your dreaming Gazettes, and Coranto's now, that talkt of ſuch formidable preparation, and ſo many hundred thouſand in an Army? Where is the threatning of Poland, and terrifying the Coſſacks with ſo many thouſand Tartarians? Where is their comming into Hungary, to begin a new Warre there? What all huſht and quiet? Why, then thine be the honour O God, and all power, and maieſtie, and goodneſſe be attributed vnto thee? For thou haſt taken pitty vpon our afflictions, and wilt ſet vpright thine owne cauſe, when the children of Edom and inhabitants of Babylon, cry downe with the walls of Ieruſalem, and inſult with clapping
their hands, to ſee the enemies of the Goſpell thriue in their outragiouſneſſe.

This then is all I would ſay vnto you by the way of Introduction, to giue God the prayſe, that the great Turke is dead ſo opportunely, whereby there is hope, that Europe ſhall be preſerved from their inuaſion, and thoſe affrightings. And the ſame God, that hath compaſsionated the generall diſtreſſes of Chriſtendome, take pittie likewiſe on the particular paſsions of Princes, that they rage not in their revenges, nor runne too violently forward in their race of bloud and deſtruction; but admit of peace and pacification to the eternall memory of their vertues, and worthineſſe.

div.head: THE STRANGLING AND DEATH, OF THE GREAT TVRKE, A STRANGE STORY.
div.p: THough I neede not ſpeake a word of former Emperours of Turkey, or their actions, or their liues, or their Alcharon, from whence the ſpeciall impoſitions on their Governerment are, firſt, to erect ſome Famous Monument toward the exaltation of their Religion. Secondly, and performe ſome memorable enterpriſe for the enlarging their Empire: yet muſt I name Mahomet the third, to keepe my ſelfe cloſer to the Story, that you may know the ſeverall paſſages in the ſame. This Mahomet left two Sonnes behind him, Achmet and Muſtapha; Achmet at 15. yeeres old was choſen Emperor, and lived ſome 15. yeeres longer, or thereabouts and although by reaſon of the peace betweene the Emperour Rodulphus of Germany, & himſelfe, as alſo the contract betweene the Pelomans & himſelfe, wherin thoſe Antiqua foedera were renewed, he did little worthy of memory, concerning Heroijck enterpriſes, and military exploites: yet he had the Fortune to keepe correſpondēcy with his Basſhawes, and Ianizaries, and tooke a courſe by enlarging their entertainement, and other ſeverall donatiues, to enlarge their heartes, and good liking towards him: ſo that he had very ſeldome mutinies, or innovation, becauſe the Viceer of the Army drew them ſtill into the field in the Summer, and the Viceer of the City, afforded them their Auncient liberty in the Winter: but at laſt there was a rebellion by the Serivano of Aſia, whom ſome confound with the name of Basſhaw of Alleppo, which was fortunately, and wiſely prevented: and in the ende of his Raigne the controverſies of the Princes of Moldavia, over wrought the Polacks to commiſerate the cauſe & wrought a miſchiefe, which was not ended without vnſpeakeable trouble: For the diſtaſtings beginning in Achmets time, could never admit of reconciliation: till Achmets Sonne came in perſon with terror, and threatnings into the fieldes of Bogdonia.

Well? Achmet dies, leaving 2. young Sonnes behind him, Oſman and another: yet ſome will preſume to ſay, that being not aboue 34 yeeres old, he had many Children, and 300 Wiues or Concubines: but before he dyed, to make all ſure, he reſolues to ſtrangle his brother Muſtapha, and according to cuſtome will leaue no Competitors in ſuch an Empire. For which purpoſe a Guard of Capagies attend at the Iron gates of the Seralio, and the Mutes are placed in a roome accordingly. Now you muſt conſider, that though they haue many wayes to enlarge their cruelties, and diſpatch offenders, yet none is ſo affrighting, as the preſenting of theſe Officers, for they never come along without death in their company, and ghaſtlines in their lookes. Sometimes an offender is carried from the Seralio, by the Officers of their Tapinaco, ſuch as we ſay Mr. of the Ordnāce, over the Sea, & in the midway a great ſtone is tyed about his neck, and he is caſt into the bottome, and then according to his greatnes, a greater Cannon is ſhot off, vnleſſe the Emperour ſend a countermand; er he be from the water: ſometimes an offender is beheaded: ſometimes throwne off a rocke: ſometimes ſet vpon by the Ianizaries, & cut in peeces, as the Haga or Captaine is limited, yet in theſe caſes as the Emperors fury is leniated, they many times eſcape: but when the Mutes come in place, all are diſplaced, againſt whom their Commiſſion is enlarged. Thus is Muſtapha to be diſpatched, but ſee how the ſtronger arme puts out the ſtrong men? the ſame night Achmet had a dreame or fearefull viſion, which ſome of the Deruices would needes preſume to rumor abroad, in this manner; that hee thought as he was entring into the 7. Towers, the princely priſon of his Predeceſſors, his brother kneeled downe before him, and cryed out, Oh when ſhal we leaue this horrible cuſtome of ſhedding innocent blood? looke among all the Heathens, and ſee, how quickly they loathed and caſt away that crying Sin of ſacrificing of humane fleſh? but in ſteede of replying he drew his Semiter to ſtrike off his head, had not one as hee conceited held it faſt, that hee could not ſtrike; whereupon he demanded angerly, what art thou? I am the good Genius of Muſtapha, and will not ſuffer him to periſh, therefore leaue: and very ſhortly ſhall ſtrange things happen in the Empire. Little thought the great Turke, to haue found a greater Greatneſſe in his ſleepe, but ſuch was the power of God, or as
the Turkes conceited the fortune of Muſtapha, that his brother Achmate contrary to all expectation the next morning after his Dreame, ſent for him into the roome of State, where he lay on as ſtately a Pallet, with all his Viceroys and Baſhaws groueling on the ground, and the principall Mufty kneeling before him reading on a booke. It ſhould ſeeme that glad tydings came firſt to the Citie; For hee was taken out of the priſon with great reſpect, and obſeruation: hee was admitted to his Gally with high ceremonies, and yet ſolemne countenances: hee was accompanied on the Sea with thouſands of boates, and tenne thouſand of weeping eyes: hee landed at the Emperours one Caska with great reſpect and modeſt ſtilneſſe: hee walked through the Garden of Cipres trees, and at laſt came to an iron gate, where his owne company left him, except two Baſhawes, who led him by the armes: the gate opens and he muſt through a gard of Cupogies, they bend to the ground, and yet looke cheerefully: till at laſt the Prince ſpake as cheerefully to the Baſhawes, ſaying What need all this quoile and ceremonies to a dying man? or tormenting of my ſoule, when I goe to the execution of my body? in all extremities there is a curteſie in diſpatch, and when a man muſt dye, Oh let him dye at once, and not be more tortured with the feare and circumſtances, then with the thing it ſelfe: they durſt not reply; but brought him into the roome, where the Mutes ſtood: whoſe preſence did no more appall him then the reſt, but that hee ſaw the cruelty confirmed, and their very ſight was worſe, then an vnreuerſable iudgement: but when hee perceiued no violent hands laid vpon him, and that he muſt yet goe further, he was the more aſtoniſhed, and the more vexed to endure ſuch a procraſtination.

At laſt he came where the Emperour lay ſicke on his Pallet, before whom his proſtitution was as the ordinary ſlaues: but contrary to all expectation he bad him riſe, and commanded certaine Perſian Carpets to be ſpread, & rich Cuſhions to be laid; on which, according to their manner, he ſate croſſe legg'd by him, and when the Mufty had raiſed the Emperor
vp a little, with a faint voyce, he thus diſcouered an vnlookt for louing heart.

Brother (ſaid hee) I am taught by ſtory, and the ſtory of Galba among the Romanes, to chuſe a Succeſſor for the common-wealth, and not an heire in my family. This made him looke vpon Piſo, as worthy to be an Emperour, becauſe hee had experience of his vertues, and not vpon his kindred, becauſe hee was vnacquainted with their ſtrength to beare ſo great a burthen: I cannot compare our greatneſſe with the Romanes, but I am ſure wee are too great for children, or fooles: I haue faire iſſue of my owne, but ſo weake armes cannot ſway the Scepter of our Othoman family, and to leaue them vnder Tutelage, Who is there worthy to aduiſe ſuch Princes, or what account can ſlaues make of the gouernment, when their owne vices ſhall ouerflow their bankes without reſtraint, and the enuie of others look vpon them rather with diſobedience, then obſeruation? therefore to auoid all tumultuous occaſions, and to make thee beleeue, thou art the charge of our Prophet Mahomet: in ſteed of death-like preſents it ſelfe in ſteed of a priſon: this is thy Pallace, and whereas thou camſt in groueling, thou ſhalt goe out triumphing: the decree of heauen will haue it ſo, and a voyce from heauen commands it ſo; only this I muſt conclude, that as I haue remembred thee, thou wilt not forget me and mine, let not cuſtome ouermaſter vertue, nor the iealouſie in Soueraignty be an enemy to thy pitty: but let young Oſman liue as I haue determined, thou ſhalt not dye: yea, the wonder is the greater, that of a captiue I haue made thee an Emperour, and in ſteed of the terrors of affliction, brought thee out to the rauiſhings of Maieſtie.

He had no ſooner done, but he began to faint, and ſo read them all a leſſon of mortality by opening a booke, wherein they ſaw death writ in Capitall letters, and himſelfe ſinking paſt recouery, which made them recouer new Spirits, and preſently bring his brother out into the Sophia, where the principall Mufty proclaimed Muſtapha Emperour, intimating to the Ianizaries the charge of Achmate, to the diſcharging
〈…〉 larges, which equalling the bounty of other Princes, ouerſwayed nicer exceptions, and ſo with great acclamations they ratified the Election, and cryed out, liue and raigne great Muſtapha. The next worke was the ſolemnity of Achmets Funerals, for whom a ſumptuous monument, and Chappell was erected, not inferiour to any of his Aunceſtors: then were Commiſſioners appointed to ouer-looke the Seralios, and ſequeſter ſuch women, as had beene carnally knowne of Achmet to their accuſtomed Pallaces, and accuſtomed manner of magnificence, and expences. Preſently followed the ſetling of the Baſhawes in their authority, in their ſeuerall Prouinces, and ouer-looking the Citie Officers with confirmation of ſuch, as were worthy. Laſt of all, his Armies and Nauies were muſtred, not that hee pretended any warre, but becauſe he would commit no Solleciſme in gouernment, or giue the Souldiers occaſion to ſuſpect, that he knew not, how to maintaine his greatneſſe: Thus is Muſtapha Emperour, and they had two yeeres triall of his diſpoſition, whereby they found him harmleſſe, and rather ſubiect to the Epithites of quiet Princes, then tranſcending Encomions of great and ſtirring Spirits.

But oh the condition of man, and inſtability of terreſtiall bleſſings! Prince Muſtopha was ſcarce warme in this throne of Soueraignty, and ſetting forward in the rare of imperiouſnes, before Scander and Mehemet Baſhaw takes the young Oſman out of the Seralio, and preſents him to the Ianizaries, a comely, ſweet young youth of nine or ten yeeres old, demanding withall, if ſuch an heire of the Othomon family were to be reiected without cauſe, or why they ſhould bring an harmleſſe Prince (as they reputed Muſtapha) into the danger of vſurpation, and differing no further from a Traytor, but that it was not imputed to him, as for Achmats Will? Empires are not ſo tranſlated, and what could they tell, but priuate men for their owne ends had wrought vpon his weaknes, making a diſeaſed tongue ſpeak that, which a healthfull heart, and perfect ſence would not conſent to: For it was not probable, that a Father would diſinherit his children for any brother in the world: Beſides, there was no triall, or cauſe either of inſufficiencie, or diſability,
and 〈…〉 not beleeue it. La • t of all, for any thing they ſaw, Muſtapha himſelfe was not ſtirring or ſtrong enough to play the Steeres man in ſuch an high built ſhip, conſidering the Seas were tempeſtuous, and many dangerous ſhores and rockes were to be paſſed by.

Theſe ſpeeches to the turbulent Ianizaries, were like fewell to fire, and the preſence of the louely youth, made them amazed at their inconſtancie: ſo that by way of penitencie and ſatisfaction, they quickly altered the acclamation of liue Muſtapha into the cries of, God ſaue young Oſman, and ſo without further diſputing, hee was aduanced into the Throne, and brought into the Seralio, when Muſtapha leaſt thought of the alteration. But now there is no remedy, he muſt needs be depoſed, and ſent priſoner once againe into the ſeauen Towers; his friends more confounded to be ſo affronted, then amazed at the alteration: yet ſuſpecting the worſt, they abandoned the Pallace, and thinking it pollicy to ſhift for themſelues, had the leſſe honeſty to neglect their Emperour: but the truth is, they ſaw manifeſt ſignes of a rebellion, and the conſpiracie was too great and too ſtrong for them to reſiſt, which made them giue way to the violence, leaſt they ſhould haue beene caried headlong to deſtruction.

Now doth Oſman begin his Phaetons flouriſh, and runneth the courſe of pleaſures with his youth, ſpending foure or fiue yeeres in wantonneſſe and iollity, while his Baſhawes ſpent the time in couetouſneſſe and ambitious ouer-ruling others: yet not without carefull ouer-looking the Ianizaries, and prouident preuenting their diſcontents, and turbulent diſpoſition: but all doth helpe; for they ouer accuſtomed to actiue imployment, and liuing vpon the ſpoile of forraigne Nations, as much as the Emperours entertainement, cried out to the warre, and when anſwere was made, that the Perſians had contracted a new league, and the Emperours of Germanies old couenants were not yet determined or ended, They preſently replyed, the indignities which the Ruſſians had offered to their neighbours the Tartarians, were not to be endured, and they need goe no further, then the piracies of the black Sea, and the iniuries of the Coſſacks and Polonians:
Nay, why ſhould they not march to the expugnation of Locpolis, and the foraging of the Countries of Moldania and Bogdonia, and ſo forward to teach Poland a better leſſon, then to diſpleaſe the Othoman Family and mightineſſe.

The Baſhawes knew, there was no replying, nor now the fire was kindled no other quenching it, then letting it conſume to cinders, wherupon they preſently anſwered, they were glad that the Souldiers were ſo memorable of the glory of the Empire, and ſo ready to imploy themſelues for the dignity of the Nation, and therefore they would not by any meanes hinder them, or the cauſe: But they ſhould find the Emperor as carefull to ſatisfie their demaunds, as they were willing to augment his Greatnes: ſo that if they would giue way vnto time for the preparing of all things fit for the Army, and the ſending for the Tartarians to accompany them in the iourney, the Emperour ſhould goe in perſon into the Field, and Poland ſoone finde, what it was to exaſperate ſuch a Maieſty.

Whereupon ſome will haue it, that there were Letters of defiance preſently ſent againſt Sigiſmond, and the Warre proclaymed by ſound of Trumpet to affright all Europe: In what manner the Turke proceeded, I will not now diſpute, ſure I am that the King of Pole made all Chriſtian Princes acquainted with the threatnings, and implored their aſſiſtance for the Oppoſition: He ſent vnto the Emperour to hearken to a Peace, if it were poſſible, and correſpondent with his Honour, that he might ſpare his Forces rather againſt the generall Enemy of Chriſtendome, then the particuler reuenges of one another: Oh bleſſed be the feet of thoſe, that bring the glad tidings of Peace, and happy is that Princely diſpoſition, that would auoyde the effuſion of Chriſtian Blood: hee ſent vnto his Holines to remember the cauſe of the Church, and the affrightings of Religion, ſo that now was the time to aſſiſt him with men and money, and if euer Poland were reputed the Bulwarke of Chriſtianity, and to be maintained accordingly, it was at this inſtant to be looked vpon with the eyes of pitty and commiſeration. For • 00000. Turkes and Tartars were in readineſſe to ouer-runne the Country, and deuoure the Inhabitants: He ſent into France by way of interceſſion to ſpare his hand frō taking ſuch fearefull reuenges on his owne people, & to ſpare him but thoſe
men, watch the wa •• es 〈◊〉 confirme, and the wrath of a Prince bring to deſtruction: he ſent into England with intimation of the terror, which ſo many barbarous Nations & people vnited, muſt needs afflict one Countrey withall, and his well deliuered diſcourſe made ſuch impreſſion on his Maieſties Princely hart, that he had a preſent ſupply both of men & money: In a word, whether did he not ſend to ſet forward the enterpriſe? and what did he not doe befitting the goodnes of a King, & the greatnes of a Generall, and heroyick Captaine? his Army was ſoone ready, and his Coſſaches prepared: by the end of Iuly he was encamped in the fields of Bogdonia, and within 8. dayes entrenched with 20. pieces of Ordnance mounted: but the Coſſacks quartered by themſelues, & after their accuſtomed manner lying betweene two Riuers, were the more emboldened to make their daily excurſions vpon the Tartars: For hauing a bridge in the reare of their Campe, with which the Turkes were vnacquainted, they quickly tranſported their men, and as quickly endemnified their enemies.

When the Gran Signeur was made acquainted with the forwardnes of theſe Polonians, and vnderſtood they were already encamu • d, and expected his comming, he was too young to apprehend any feare, & not olde enough to lay the blame of his retardance where it was: therfore they made the more haſt, when he vnderſtood the occaſion, and ſo according to former preparation, the eſtabliſhment of diuers Gouernments, the ordering the Prouinces, the ſetling the great Citty, the muſtring his Gallyes, the guarding of his Caſtles, and the watching of the blacke Sea: the Tartars vnited themſelues to his Army, & both together made a body of 200000. which with all magnificent preparation he preſented in the ſame Fields, and within ſight of the Polonians, where he pitched his Imperiall Tent, and ſetled himſelfe with vnparaleld Maieſty: the high Prieſts and Doctors of Law attended him, the two great Baſhawes accompanied him, the throng of Ianizaries waited vpon him, and the fry of Tartars brought the Cariages vp apace.

When all thinges were ſetled, the Tartars after their accuſtomed manner with great clamours and outcryes, and with as great multitudes gaue vpon the Polonians, and thought to haue
made but one battaile & day of tryall of the buſines, but when they came to paſſe ouer Riuers, and aſſaile Trenches, when they heard the thunders of 20 Pieces of Ordnance, and felt the miſchiefe and damage: when they were encountred with 10000. well armed Horſe, and driuen backe with the fury of couragious hearts: they knew not what to ſay, and leſſe to doe; nay, though the Ianizaries came as a ſecond vnto them, and brought many field Pieces to anſwer the diſcurteſie of their Camp Ordnance, yet by reaſon they had not the diſcipline of Gabions, they were ſubiect to the greater deſtruction, and the Souldier wanting Armor found themſelues too weake for the Coſſacks: whereupon they retreated, & were altogether appawled to be ſo diſapointed, which whē Scander Baſhaw perceiued, he tooke an opportunity of exprobrating their audatiouſnes, and chiding their oſtentation, whereas now they could performe nothing, which he did as ſome report to this or the like purpoſe.

Now, you that are ſo powerfull in inſolency and tumults, and were ſo forward to the War, that we muſt either take the Field to ſpend your humors, and ſatisfie your impatience, or be taken by you, & ſuffer the indignity of your outrages, what ſay you now to the Warre? what can you doe to theſe men? nay, what will you doe for the Emperors Honor, and your own reputation? well, ſeeing you ſee by experience, that the times are changed, and the diſcipline of Warre muſt take you out other leſſons of fury, leaue your fooliſh finding fault with your friends: and ſpend your courages vpon your enemies? there is now no retiring by Mutinies, but ſetting forward vpon aduantages, you muſt either force theſe Trenches, or be enforced to indure a ſlaughter: But I will now anſwer for you, what is paſt is remedileſſe, we come to Fight, and I know, you are reſolute to play the men, therefore follow me, and I will leade you the way to death or Glory: wherupon without any reply, they came forward with 50000. and vnder the ſecurity of a rowling Trench gaue a braue Camizado on the Polonian Campe, with many pieces of Ordnance, which they mounted vpon prety bankes, as the Pyoners caſt vp the earth before them.

But as they were in this forwardnes rhe Coſſackes came ſo violently vpon the vnarmed Tartars, that they were ſubiect to
a great ſlaughter, ſo that both they and the Ianizaries were glad to retire with loſſe, and the young Emperor vnacquainted with the Warre, was yet acquainted with Oathes and Curſes, to chide both himſelfe and Fortune. At laſt the Baſhawes ſeeing no remedy and finding ſo great obſtacles of their attempts, proiected the preſeruation of the Emperors perſon; but it may be to ſecure their owne liues, & ſo entrenched themſelues, being (as they ſaid) the firſt time that euer ſo great an Army of Turkes was encloſed within walles, by which occaſion, neceſſity compeld them to confeſſe, they had new worke in hand, and that there was nothing ſo eaſie, as to cry to the warre, but nothing ſo difficult as to returne with Victory.

In this manner they lay all the Summer looking vpon one another with reuengefull eyes, and taking the aduantage of ſo many Sallies, that the Turke loſt at leaſt in ſeuerall Skirmiſhes 50000. men: For many times they met about the ſeeking of Victuall, and there fought it out: many times they encountred in forraging, and getting prouiſion for their Horſes: many times their courages were ſo exaſperated, that with equall incounters and appointed Sallies they returned home againe, finding the iſſue nothing but ſlaughter and bloud, and many times they determined to deceiue one another by taking the Riuers and paſſing the Foords, which ended not without deſtruction, and periſhing of whole Companies. As for ſet Battails, or one dayes tryall by equall agreement of both parties, it neuer came to ſo formidable a buſines, or remarkable aduenture: and therefore I can but wonder at the ſhameleſſe reports of ſtrange men, and weake Certificates by Corantes from Foraine parts, eſpecially to haue them Printed, to talke of ſo many Thouſands ſlaine, the Prince kill'd, Sigiſmond defeated, and the whole Army put to flight, when yet as I ſaid, there was neuer any ſuch matter, nor any ſet Battaile fought.

Yet although the Polonians had rather the better, then the Turkes, they did not runne away ſo faſt with proſperity, but they were ſubiect to many inconueniences, and they ſawe plainely the warres were no May-games: For they endu red both Hunger and Colde, ſlacknes of payment, and their entertainment came many times ſhort: The Noble

The noble Generall died in the Campe, the Prince lay ſicke of a Feuer, their horſe miſcarried, and other lamentable effects taught them extraordinary patience, which made them attend good conditions of peace, and when they found they might be entertained, they were not ſcrupulous or thought it any deſparagement to propoſe the ſame.

When the Baſhawes were thus diſappointed (eſpecially Mehemet Baſhaw) who was euer an enemy to the Moldauian buſines, and that he ſaw the yong Emperour euery way diſcontented, but eſpecially with himſelfe, as blaming his owne vnhappineſſe, that hee ſhould in the firſt triall of his manhood be ſo vnfortunate, as to open the doore of Chriſtian apprehenſion; that the Othoman fame was now at the higheſt, and the Turkiſh Empire ſubiect to diminution: hee went another way to worke, and perſwaded the yong Prince to make tryall of another time, and peace for the preſent: nay he did talke of another countrey, to which when the Turke angerly replyed, he would die firſt, hee enforced the argument that it ſhould be to his honour, and the Polack ſhould ſeeke it with great mediation.

It is ſaid, the yong Emperour ſhed teares, and was more afraid of his diſceputation among his ſouldiers, then glad of any pacification of the preſent troubles; yet neceſſitie had no law, and he was in the end compelled to the propoſed compoſition. But how? By a polliticke contriuing the buſines, and ſecret workings of more nimble ſpirits: for preſently a Prieſt of Moldauia was ſet on worke to go among the Polonians, and by way of generall complaint againſt the outragious effects of warre, to enlarge the happineſſe of peace, and inferre what a bleſſing it were to procure the ſame: whereupon hee was brought to the yong Prince of Poland, and commanders of the Army, with whom hee at laſt preuailed ſo well, and ſo farre, that they ſent a ſolemne Embaſſie to the great Turke, as he lay entrenched in the fields, to entreate a peace, and deſire the renouation of the antiqua pucta, which had been euer betweene the two nations. The Turke had learnd his leſſon ſo well, that hee ſeemed to make the
matter ſtrange and of great humiliation, if he ſhould conſent thereunto, and rather a curteſie granted then a neceſſitie impoſed, and ſo deferred them a while, till at laſt (as if he had bin ouer-wrought by the interceſſion and mediation of his Baſhawes) he was contented to capitulate the matter, and after many meetings, and a great deale of conference, articles were drawne, and confirmed with a kinde of ſolemnity, and proclaimed by ſound of trumpet in both the campes.

But ſee the condition of men, and the inconueniences that great Emperours are ſubiect vnto? for all the Ianizaries themſelues neither durſt, nor could maintaine the warre any longer, and were indeed affronted with an ouer-maſtring power, and an ouer-ruling diſcipline of warre: yet they rather complained of the Emperor, as being vnfortunate, then their owne cowardice, as being ouer-mated, and ſo brake vp the campe with a kinde of murmuring and repining. The great Turke tooke eaſie iourneys toward Andrinopolis, where he diſcharged the Tartars, and ſent moſt of his Ianizaries before hand to Conſtantinople. Sigiſmond king of Poland raiſed his army, and rewarding the Coſſacks, diſmiſſed them home againe into their country: he went in perſon to Leopolis, from whence (by this time Oſman was come to the great cittie) he ſent a ſolemne Embaſſador to be there a Leiger, as it had bin in former times.

By Chriſtmas Oſman comes home, and had the accuſtomed acclamations of the people, with all the ceremonies of his returne, whereupon he goes in great pompe to the Sophia, and had the vſefull guard of his Court Ianizaries to attend him: but within ſhort ſpace many fearefull accidents appalled them all, and ſuch a miſchiefe followed, as they could not example by any preſident. Firſt, they were aſtoniſhed at a blazing Comet, about which many men did raue in the interpretation. Secondly, they were afrighted at a great fire hapning amongſt the Iewes, which they preſaged ominous to the gouernment. Thirdly, a ſore earthquake made their hearts quake for feare: but this is ſo vſuall in thoſe parts by reaſon of the aſcending vp the hills, and many Cauerns vnder
ground, that they needed not haue made it, or taken it for any ſigne of diſpleaſure. Fourthly, the Sea ſwelling extraordinarily, and the winde from the Southweſt driuing the billowes into the corner of the harbour, made ſuch a noyſe and formidable ſound, as catching the tackles of the ſhips and gallies in his whiſtling, that they were affraid euen of common accidents.

Laſt of all, and worſt of all, by reaſon of the great concourſe of people, and reſort of ſtrangers, ſuch a famine happened in the city, and dearth in the countrey, that euery one complained, and though it was remedileſſe by the pollicy of man, yet was the fault layed vpon Superiours, and the Emperour himſelfe did not eſcape ſcandall and calumniation.

For while the Ʋiceers and principall Officers endeuoured the common good, and ſtudied the Weale publike, which could not be done, but by diſcharging the Citie of multitudes of Inhabitants; all was interpreted to be done for their priuate wealth, and ambitious ouer-ruling of others: but when it came to the diſcharging of many Ianizaries and ſouldiers out of the Citie, to liue as it were in garriſon in the Countrey, and that the Emperour was ſlacke in their Donatiues, and former allowances out of his Treaſurie; they ſtormed beyond meaſure, and threatened the Ʋiceers and Baſhawes to haue a better account of the Buſineſſe; crying out, they would not be quiet, till they were imployed in one Seruice, or other. To this the Ʋiceer replyed, that hee wondered at their baſeneſſe and audaciouſneſſe, that hauing fayled in all their Enterpriſes, they durſt yet complaine of any accident, more then their owne cowardize. As for the ſatisfying of wilfull men, they would not violate the Lawes of Nations, or infringe the contracted Peace with other Kingdomes, to appeaſe the mutinies of turbulent ſpirits, who, if they might haue their owne demaunds, knew not what to demaund. As for your ſelues, what would you haue? you know the treaſure is exhauſted,
& the dearth is ſo great, that we haue not ſufficient to buy vs bread: and for your murmuring and repinings againſt the Maieſtie of the Prince, as if he alone were branded with misfortune, or borne vnder ſome diſaſtrous conſtellation; how can this be, that with the ſame hands whereof you boaſt to vphold the Empire, you will preſumptuouſly pull it in peeces; but I ſee the reaſon, this is for lacke of diſcipline to make you know your ſelues, and ſo I cannot reſemble you better then vnto ſtinking weedes and nettles, which cruſhed hard, looſe their force, and cannot hurt at all; but gently handled, will ſting and endamage one.

Till this they were not much enraged, but now no flames could exaeſtuate more then fury and rauings: for they dared to condemne the Viceeres, and cryed out on their childiſh and vnfortunate Emperour, that hauing neither ſufficient wit, nor courage to gouerne the State, muſt be ouer-ruled by ſuch, as made pollicie, couetouſneſſe; and ambition, the ſupportation of their greatneſſe, and the commanding voice to do what they liſt, without controule: yea ſuch was the refractary diſobedienee of them at this time, that many offred to lay violent hands both on himſelfe and his ſeruants, and had not the Haga or their Captaine come in to their pacification, they had queſtionleſſe begun a warre of miſchiefe, and inſolent trouble.

Well, they are quieted all this time; the ſuſpition of further vprores and miſchiefes made the whole citty to ſtand vpon their guard, and euery Baſhaw ſtrengthned himſelfe with as many friends as he could, and the Viceer for ſecuritie of the Emperor aſſembled the Chauſes, Cappogies, Spahies, and Ianizaries of the Court to guard the Seraglio, and watch the paſſages. Now you muſt conſider that there hath been euer enmity and emulation between theſe Ianizaries of the pallace and Ianizaries at large, whereupon when theſe vnderſtood, that they were appointed for oppoſition, and ſaw plainly there was a deuiſe to ſingle thē out, that ſo they might be brought in queſtion for their mutinies: they reſolued with Heroſtratus, that burnt the temple of Diana, to performe ſome
nefarious and notorious outrage, to be remembred to poſteritie, or be regiſtred for an exorbitant action: and ſo in multitudes paſt beleefe, they ſet vpon the Emperours Seraglio, broke open the yron Gates, diſſipated the Guards, ſeized on the Women, tooke as many Baſhawes as they could: but the chiefeſt reaſon why they offered this outrage, is as followeth.

Sultan Oſman hauing taken out of the Treaſurie of ſeuen Towers a good quantitie of Gold, and being therewith paſſed ouer into Aſia, with reſolution to goe vnto Mecca: the great Mufti, his father in law, hauing laboured with all the greateſt of the Court, whom it pleaſed not at all, that their Emperour being ſo young, ſhould make ſo farre and long a Voyage; not being able to remoue him from his reſolution, as hee deſired, did in pollicy ſpread a rumour abroad, that the Emperour had taken ſo many Millions of Gold away with him, purpoſing therewith to make new Warres againſt his Enemies, notwithſtanding the ſmall ſatisfaction hee had giuen in the late Warres againſt Poland. Which comming to the vnderſtanding of the Spahi and Ianizaries, they riſe, and in a furie ranne vnto the Tower wherein Sultan Muſtapha was impriſoned, and taking him thereout, ſaluted him Emperour, who was lawfully elected by the father of Oſman. This comming to the knowledge of the young Emperour, hee ſent his Grand Ʋiſier and the Aga of his Ianizaries, to appeaſe the ſame, who were preſently ſlaine by the ſouldiers in their furie. By which accident, the young Emperour, to remedie this diſorder, being forced to come himſelfe in perſon, was inſtantly made priſoner, and brought to the preſence of his vnckle Muſtapha; who hauing framed Iudgement againſt him, cauſed him to be carryed priſoner to the ſame Tower where hee himſelfe had beene priſoner, and the night following to be ſtrangled, with two of his ſonnes but lately borne: Which was moſt inhumanely commanded by Muſtapha, his owne vnckle; who for the more ſecuritie, to keepe the Empire from another vſu • pa • ion, cauſed it to be effected.

It is alſo written, that although hee condiſcended to deliuer into their hands all the chiefe men they required, which were the principalleſt of the Ottomans Court, who afterward were all ſlaine with the ſword; though hee proffered them great gifts, yea to encreaſe their ſtipends, and other preferments: all could not auayle, to aſſwage the anger of the ſouldiers.

It is further reported, that the Emperour had giuen in charge to the Keeper of the Tower, that hee ſhould ſuffer Muſtapha to die of hunger, to auoid thoſe diſgraces and accidents which ſince are befallen him: and it ſeemeth hee had alreadie ſuſtained ſome want of foode; for ſo ſoone as hee came to be ſet at libertie by the people, hee preſently cryed out for Water, ſaying, hee was ready to die of thirſt, and that if hee had not come out of priſon when hee did, hee preſently had yeelded vp his life, being (as hee ſaid) wonderfully preſerued by his God Mahomet.

When the young Emperour Oſman was brought to his preſence, hee kneeled on his knees, and craued pardon of him for his life, as heretofore Ottoman had done the like to him: but Muſtapha anſwered, ſaying, that fauour I haue receiued commeth from heauen, and not from your hand.

Hee afterwards cauſed the Grand Mufti, the great Turkes vnckle, to be put to death, who had formerly bereaued him of ſo great an Empire, and made him a Maſul, which is as much to ſay, as a man depoſed from his Office. Hee placed in the roome of the dead Viſier, Daut Paſcias, a man of great wiſedome, and one that had demeaned himſelfe well in matters of greateſt importance.

It is alſo ſaid, that the death of the young Emperour is very ill taken by the ſouldiers, for they deſired the death of none of them, but that they might be reconciled, and gouerne them as their naturall Lords and Princes, as they beſt could agree; and the rather, for that by reaſon of the death of the aforeſaid Oſman, the whole race of the Ottomans is extinguiſhed, if the two children are put to death, as is reported, for that Sultan Muſtapha, now Emperour, is held vnable for generation.

Others report, that Sultan Oſman was not as yet gone ouer into Aſia, but was vpon going, and that the Mufti and other his adherents not being able to remoue him from his reſolution, did vſe this but as a deuice to diuert him, caſting this rumour among the people, viz. the Spahi and the Ianizaries, as is aforeſaid, which happened to his ruine, and a declination and ending of the Ottoman Empire.

To come to a concluſion; neuer was ſo violent an act ſo ſuddenly performed, nor ſo quickly repented: For the Ianizaries ſtood amazed at their owne villanie, & by night there was not a man ſeene, that durſt iuſtifie their treaſons; for they fled for the preſent, no man knew whither, and thoſe which remained, were afraid to ſtand for the glory of the Houſe of Oſman, but they would liue and die in the obedience of a worthy Emperor.

But how this vprore ceaſed, or tumult was appeaſed: what offendors bee taken, or how puniſhed: what Baſhawes bee ſlaine, or from whence others are admitted: by what meanes the Doctors of the Law came together againe, or whether they eſcaped; if you long to know, I long as much to informe you: which (if I may doe) I will doe, according to the next Certificate that comes.
